intro: Scirpus humbertii, commonly known as the Humbert's bulrush, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland environments in southern Africa. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges, and is characterized by its triangular stems and dense clusters of flowering spikes. The plant typically grows in shallow water or moist soil, thriving in marshes and along the edges of lakes and rivers. Its flowering season occurs during the wet season, producing small, greenish-brown flowers that are wind-pollinated. Scirpus humbertii plays an important ecological role in stabilizing wetland soils and providing habitat for various aquatic and terrestrial organisms.
